#lore

I think there are cool characters, who as part of their identity are also old ladies, that could be a good fit in League of Legends. I don't think 'League doesn't have one' is a sufficient argument by itself though, for any concept. League doesn't have a harpy for example, a classic monster from myth and other fantasy settings. That doesn't mean we should necessarily make one though. Whether or not a harpy allows us to tell new stories, offer new gameplay, create a different personality, show a distinct visual silhouette etc better than other concepts is what we're interested in. We'll always have more concepts than we'll be able to make, so comparing what an idea lets us do is really important. 

As far as old lady goes I think there's a lot that piece of background goes well with. If a character's physically old, but still able to compete with other champions, there's got to be something else impressive about them. That could be a wealth of knowledge and training, or massive willpower and resilience built up over a lifetime. They might move differently to many other champions, much more controlled, precise motions for example, rather than the more flashy speed/strength based combat of others. They'll almost certainly have a pretty different outlook on things from characters who are still pretty early on in their lives, who are still mastering their powers or figuring out their place in the world. 

Age by itself though isn't a justification for making a character. It's a means to an end, not the end in and of itself, just like any other character trait.

Elise and Lissandra are the only ones from above that we actually have a reason to believe are several decades old or more. Kallista is a vengeful spirit or specter. Lulu however is canonically hundreds of years old.

Kayle and Morganna are over 10,000 years old (and they are immortal).

Kalista's age is never mentioned as far as I know, but in her lore it references eternity a lot so it's entirely possible for her to be a few centuries old (at least).

The truth is that the OP is looking for a particular aesthetic as opposed to actual age, because there are plenty of ancient females in the League!

Just to jump in, I'm going to take a swing and say that Kayle and Morganna's immortality is probably the "immunity to time and  disease" variant. I'd guess they can still be killed through conventional means, seeing as how a war without anyone ever dying would get old pretty quickly (badum tish).

> [{quoted}](name=Meddler,realm=NA,application-id=A8FQeEA8,discussion-id=vgnG3WYN,comment-id=0010,timestamp=2015-08-16T03:13:37.585+0000)
>
> As far as old lady goes I think there's a lot that piece of background goes well with. If a character's physically old, but still able to compete with other champions, there's got to be something else impressive about them. That could be a wealth of knowledge and training, or massive willpower and resilience built up over a lifetime. They might move differently to many other champions, much more controlled, precise motions for example, rather than the more flashy speed/strength based combat of others. They'll almost certainly have a pretty different outlook on things from characters who are still pretty early on in their lives, who are still mastering their powers or figuring out their place in the world. 

Well, um. I mean. They're Champions. Of course there's something impressive about them. We've got sword-wielding knights who can go toe-to-toe with giant Void monsters. We've got little girls who can brawl with barbarian kings and Ascended guardians. I have trouble seeing how "being old" is a serious problem. That's kind of like saying, "Hmm, this Thor character, I'm just not sure how a Viking with a short-handled hammer could really stand up to people with laser guns. He might need a giant mech or something to make it make sense." If you literally parse, for example, Caitlyn as "a stern officer of the law who's a pretty good marksman", or Garen as "this guy with a sword who's really excited about yelling Demacia", you've got some serious setting cohesion problems.

That said, sure, older Champions are usually portrayed as relying on cunning and skill rather than pure brawn. Swain doesn't run around doing dive-rolls and hurling cars at people. He grumbles at them, tells them to get off his lawn, and then morphs into a giant bird and eats them.

I don't think being old's any sort of problem for a champion, let alone a serious one. I don't feel it's anymore a justification for a character by itself than 'tall' is however - might be an important part of a character's identity but isn't an argument by itself.

And yet there are a bunch of middle-aged men and {{champion:26}} {{champion:50}}.  When 70ish female champions are out and all of them are either "ageless" or look under 35 and have the same body type (unless yordle/under 18), it speaks to a massive blind spot.  "Women who aren't swimsuit models" isn't anywhere near as specific as "harpy".  You'd have to be a Rito champion designer to think otherwise.

Not sure where you're getting the impression I'm arguing for swimsuit models as the way to make female champions. Over the last couple of years we've deliberately targeted a wider range of champions in many regards, which has included, but isn't limited to, body type and gender. Our female champions don't have as much variety as our male champions, and I personally feel that's been a missed opportunity in the past because it means we missed out on cool types of character, story, theme and gameplay opportunities.

'Old lady' though's not a fleshed out character, but a small part of an individual, in the same way that Swain isn't just 'old man'. Start talking about old female characters that are actual characters and we get somewhere really interesting. Examples of that I think are well done are M as portrayed by Judi Dench in various Bond films say, or the Dowager Countess in Downton Abbey as played by Maggie Smith. Flemeth from Dragon age as someone mentioned below's a great example to me from another fantasy setting, as are Granny Weatherwax/Nanny Ogg (Discworld).

I don't know about you, but {{champion:429}} isn't what I would consider "swimsuit model" material. Yes, Riot has, in the past, quite oversexualized their female champs, even {{champion:10}} and {{champion:89}}, which aren't supposed to be swimsuit models, still have that body, coupled with breast armor.

However, recently, we can see Riot move away from this almost perverted look towards female champs. The skins released are not that bad, and the female champs released are only sexualized if their lore permits it. For example, {{champion:60}}, of whom seducts her victims into being dragged back to the Shadow Iles. 

{{champion:131}} really isn't that bad, and also the new {{champion:114}}. {{champion:222}} is another example, and she actually sparked a debate on Riot's look towards female champs due to her lack of.......assets. These champs all fit their lore quite well, instead of just fitting that "swimsuit model" theme.

None of these are clear counterexamples of the body type or age.  Some of them are just moodier or ghostier or wear more.  And Jinx looks 14 years old, more or less as I said earlier.  No tank or brawler champions that look like weightlifters, etc.

I upvoted this.  Now, I may be overthinking this, but I'd want to be super careful if the champ team came up with a concept that also happened to be an old woman.  A lot of the time, when people think "old lady" they get a mixture of vibes or stereotypes:

 * Evil witch
 * Untrustworthy hag
 * Sickly/dying crone
 * Kindly granny
 * Doddering/harmless old biddy
 * Gossipping/meddling matriarch

Basically, they split into two camps - untrustworthy and malicious witch/hag, and the harmless and mostly ineffectual grandmother type.  Neither of these are particularly healthy stereotypes and not usually something people aspire to be (or play).  I wouldn't suggest for a second that the champs team would fall into such easy pitfalls if they came up with one, but I am aware of the worry that ageism, and some (particularly Western) cultures often equate youth with good, and old with bad.

Consider me selfish, but I'd like if whatever the next aged champ we create (that people obviously identify as being visibly aged - Lulu and Lissandra need not apply) to be something that is seen as not only powerful as all champs are, but a force for good.  That might needlessly limit the options, and I know that many here would really love to get their teeth into playing a full-on wicked Baba Yaga crone (I know I would!) but I would like at least one supernaturally awesome and aspirational old lady before we give the world another example of the examples above.

(Characters like Super Gran, Professor Minerva McGonagall, and LoK-era Toph Bei Fong, are three cliche-busting examples.  God, it's been a long time since I thought about Super Gran...)
Don't forget Granny Weatherwax from Terry Pratchet's Diskworld!  All sorts of anti-cliche, and yet strangely right in there with the tropes...

Fucking THANK YOU for actually addressing the point of this thread.

The very first point of conversation that should have happened here is "oh so you want an old lady champion? What would you think she should do and how can she be unique in League of Legends?"

Instead Meddler and probably 85% of the people in this thread got baited into this stupid conversation about sexualization which is completely irrelevant and unrelated, except to say that "literally nobody finds old ladies sexy" which is not actually true (old men who are married to them probably find them sexy for example,) but even if it were, has nothing to do with why this thread exists. Anybody participating in that conversation is hijacking this thread for their own agenda, whether it's pro or con "female sexualization." That is just blatantly **NOT** what this thread is for.

You make good points about how there's not very many archetypes that "old ladies" fall into, they really are just the ones you mentioned, and honestly, if it's between good witch/bad witch, and you want to ask what a good witch looks like, I think sadly you already have that champion: Lulu.

Lulu fits perfectly into the "good witch" archetype, she has witch-like nature-affinity (she has a sprite [nature spirit] that follows her around like a familiar) and is more about being harmlessly mischievous than actually combative. Some of this is coming from memory since I haven't looked at the old lore in a long time but she's either from or lives currently, or occasionally travels to this place called "the glade" right? That seems like some sort of Legend-esque land of raw natural magic. Lulu has a happy-go-lucky personality that is completely carefree. She says things that indicate that she has no worries in life and messes with people in funny ways (like polymorphing them temporarily, whether it be into a harmless forest critter, or making them huge) to maybe send the message that these warmongers need to lighten up sometimes. One can't help but get the feeling that Lulu is actually capable of immense displays of destructive power, but she chooses not to use her magic that way because she's more of a Chaotic Good nature.

Now I say all this to basically just say that the "good witch" archetype is unfortunately already in the game and it doesn't belong to "an old woman champion." I mean, maybe you could make a "granny Lulu" skin and people might buy it, but it seems like if we do want an "old lady" champ, she might have to fit into more of the "evil witch/baba yaga" archetype, unless someone can come up with another in-context role for an old woman to play in League of Legends.

Now the other point that I started to make at the very beginning was about what the champions abilities are. Believe me, I know that in a competitive setting, aesthetic is important but it's not the be all end all for everyone playing the game, and the more competitive you are the less you care. If the champion has abilities that are really good, she will get played no matter what she looks like. So the discussion should really be more about what the character should do, than what they should look like. In the end it's the thing that matters the most, and it honestly bothers me to see so much discussion about the other, far less important issues.
